message_1: Suppose a sample of 30 students has an average math score of 85 with a standard deviation of 10. Calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true population mean math score.
message_2:
To calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true population mean math score, we will use the formula:

CI = x̄ ± (t * (s / √n))

where:
- CI is the confidence interval
- x̄ is the sample mean (85 in this case)
- t is the t-score corresponding to the desired confidence level (95% in this case) and degrees of freedom (n-1)
- s is the sample standard deviation (10 in this case)
- n is the sample size (30 in this case)

First, we need to find the t-score. Since we have a sample size of 30, we have 29 degrees of freedom (n-1). For a 95% confidence interval and 29 degrees of freedom, the t-score is approximately 2.045.

Now we can plug in the values into the formula:

CI = 85 ± (2.045 * (10 / √30))

CI = 85 ± (2.045 * (10 / 5.477))

CI = 85 ± (2.045 * 1.826)

CI = 85 ± 3.736

So, the 95% confidence interval for the true population mean math score is approximately (81.264, 88.736).
